label: paragraph

line: The scope of the present Report was intended to be national in scale. It was determined,
label: paragraph

line: therefore, that any effort to assess the risk of mercury to a given species living in a defined location
label: paragraph

line: would be inappropriate. Instead, an effort was made to compare mercury exposure and effects in a
label: paragraph

line: general way using data collected from throughout the country and, in so doing, to develop qualitative
label: paragraph

line: statements about risk.
label: paragraph

line: Consistent with this broader-scale approach, an effort was made to derive a wildlife criterion
label: paragraph

line: (WC) value for mercury that is protective of piscivorous wildlife. This WC is defined as the
label: paragraph

line: concentration of mercury in water that, if not exceeded, protects avian and mammalian wildlife
label: paragraph

line: populations from adverse effects resulting from ingestion of surface waters and from ingestion of aquatic
label: paragraph

line: life taken from these surface waters. The health of wildlife populations may, therefore, be considered the
label: paragraph

line: assessment endpoint of concern. Although not generally derived for the purpose of ecological risk
label: paragraph

line: assessment, WC values incorporate the same type of exposure and effects information used in more
label: paragraph

line: standard approaches. Such calculations also provide for a simple assessment of risk in any given
label: paragraph

line: situation; that is, by determining whether the concentration of mercury in water exceeds the criterion
label: paragraph

line: value.
label: paragraph

line: The principal factors used to select wildlife species for WC development were: (1) exposure to
label: paragraph

line: bioaccumulative contaminants; (2) species distributions; (3) availability of information with which to
label: paragraph

line: calculate criterion values; and (4) evidence for bioaccumulation and/or adverse effects. All of the species
label: paragraph

line: selected feed on or near the top of aquatic food webs. The avian species selected were the bald eagle
label: paragraph

line: (Haliaeetus leucocephalus), osprey (Pandion haliaetus), common loon (Gavia immer) and belted
label: paragraph

line: kingfisher (Ceryle alcyon).
label: paragraph

line: otter (Lutra canadensis).
label: paragraph

line: The mammalian species selected were the mink (Mustela vison) and river
label: paragraph

line: Because this assessment depends to a large extent on the assignment of BAFs for mercury in fish
label: paragraph

line: at trophic levels 3 and 4, an effort was made to review published field data from which these BAFs could
label: paragraph

line: be estimated. A Monte Carlo analysis was then performed to characterize the variability around these
label: paragraph

line: estimates. The results of this effort are reported in Appendix D of Volume III and are summarized in
label: paragraph

line: Table ES-2.
label: paragraph

line: A WC value for mercury was estimated as the ratio of an RfD, defined as the chronic NOAEL (in
label: paragraph

line: µg/kg bw/d), to an estimated mercury consumption rate, referenced to water concentration using a BAF.
label: paragraph

line: Individual wildlife criteria are provided in Table ES-3. This approach is similar to that used in non-
label: paragraph

line: cancer human health risk assessment and was employed previously to estimate a WC for mercury in the
label: paragraph

line: Water Quality Guidance for the Great Lakes System (GLWQI). The present effort differs, however,
label: paragraph

line: from that of the GLWQI in that the entire analysis was conducted on a methylmercury basis. Additional
label: paragraph

line: differences resulted from the availability of new data, including measured residue levels in fish and
label: paragraph

line: water, and a re-evaluation of the toxicity data from which RfD estimates were derived. In this Report, a
label: paragraph

line: more sensitive endpoint was selected for mammalian species, with the goal of assessing the full range of
label: paragraph

line: effects of mercury. These changes reflect the amount of discretion allowed under Agency Risk
label: paragraph

line: Assessment Guidelines.
label: paragraph

line: Species-specific WC values for methylmercury were estimated for selected avian and
label: paragraph

line: mammalian wildlife (identified above). A final WC was then calculated as the lowest mean of WC
label: paragraph

line: ES-6
label: paragraph

line: values for each of the two taxonomic classes (birds and mammals).
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: Table ES-3
label: heading

line: The final WC for methylmercury
label: paragraph

line: Wildlife Criteria for Methylmercury
label: heading

line: individual WC values calculated for mammalian species, and was estimated to be 50 picograms (pg)
label: paragraph

line: methylmercury/L water.
label: paragraph

line: The WC for methylmercury can be expressed as a corresponding mercury residue in fish though
label: paragraph

line: the use of appropriate BAFs. Using the BAFs presented in Table ES-2 (50th percentile), a WC of 50
label: paragraph

line: pg/L corresponds to methylmercury concentrations in fish of 0.077 µg/g and 0.346 µg/g for trophic levels
label: paragraph

line: 3 and 4, respectively. In addition, a WC for total mercury can be calculated using an estimate of
label: paragraph

line: methylmercury as a proportion of total mercury in water. Based upon a survey of speciation data, the
label: paragraph

line: best current estimate of dissolved methylmercury as a proportion of total dissolved mercury was
label: paragraph

line: determined to be 0.078. Using this value, a methylmercury WC of 50 pg/L corresponds to a total
label: paragraph

line: dissolved mercury WC of 641 pg/L. An additional correction is needed if the WC is to be expressed as
label: paragraph

line: the amount of total mercury in unfiltered water. The available data, although highly variable, suggest
label: paragraph

line: that on average total dissolved mercury comprises about 70 percent of that contained in unfiltered water.
label: paragraph

line: Making this final correction results in a WC of 910 pg/L (unfiltered, total mercury), which is
label: paragraph

line: approximately 70 percent of the value published previously in the GLWQI.
label: paragraph

line: Conclusions
label: heading

line: The following conclusions are presented in approximate order of degree of certainty in the
label: heading

line: conclusion, based on the quality of the underlying database.
label: heading

line: with greater certainty to those with lesser certainty.
label: heading

line: The conclusions progress from those
label: heading

line: Mercury emitted to the atmosphere deposits on watersheds and is translocated to waterbodies. A
label: paragraph

line: variable proportion of this mercury is transformed by abiotic and biotic chemical reactions to
label: paragraph

line: organic derivatives, including methylmercury. Methylmercury bioaccumulates in individual
label: paragraph

line: organisms, biomagnifies in aquatic food chains and is the most toxic form of mercury to which
label: paragraph

line: wildlife are exposed.
label: paragraph

line: ES-7
label: paragraph

line: The proportion of total mercury in aquatic biota that exists as methylmercury tends to increase
label: paragraph

line: with trophic level. Greater than 90% of the mercury contained in freshwater fish exists as
label: paragraph

line: methylmercury. Methylmercury accumulates in fish throughout their lifetime, although changes
label: paragraph

line: in concentration as a function of time may be complicated by growth dilution and changing
label: paragraph

line: dietary habits.
label: paragraph

line: Piscivorous avian and mammalian wildlife are exposed to mercury primarily through
label: paragraph

line: consumption of contaminated fish and accumulate mercury to levels above those in prey items.
label: paragraph

line: Toxic effects on piscivorous avian and mammalian wildlife due to the consumption of
label: paragraph

line: contaminated fish have been observed in association with point source releases of mercury to the
label: paragraph

line: environment.
label: paragraph

line: Concentrations of mercury in the tissues of wildlife species have been reported at levels
label: paragraph

line: associated with adverse health effects in laboratory studies with the same species.
label: paragraph

line: Piscivorous birds and mammals receive a greater exposure to mercury than any other known
label: paragraph

line: receptors.
label: paragraph

line: BAFs for mercury in fish vary widely; however, field data are sufficient to calculate
label: paragraph

line: representative means for different trophic levels. These means are believed to be better estimates
label: paragraph

line: of mercury bioaccumulation in natural systems than values derived from laboratory studies. The
label: paragraph

line: recommended methylmercury BAFs for tropic levels 3 and 4 are 1,600,000 and 6,800,000,
label: paragraph

line: respectively (dissolved basis).
label: paragraph

line: Based upon knowledge of mercury bioaccumulation in fish, and of feeding rates and the identity
label: paragraph

line: of prey items consumed by piscivorous wildlife, it is possible to rank the relative exposure of
label: paragraph

line: different piscivorous wildlife species. Of the six wildlife species selected for detailed analysis,
label: paragraph

line: the relative ranking of exposure to mercury is this: kingfisher > otter > loon = osprey = mink >
label: paragraph

line: bald eagle. Existing data are insufficient to estimate the exposure of the Florida panther relative
label: paragraph

line: to that of the selected species.
label: paragraph

line: Local emissions sources (<50 km from receptors) have the potential to increase the exposure of
label: paragraph

line: piscivorous wildlife well above that due to sources located more than 50 km from the receptors
label: paragraph

line: (i.e., "remote" sources).
label: paragraph

line: Field data are insufficient to conclude whether the mink, otter or other piscivorous mammals
label: paragraph

line: have suffered adverse effects due to airborne mercury emissions.
label: paragraph

line: Field data are insufficient to conclude whether the loon, wood stork, great egret, or other
label: paragraph

line: piscivorous wading birds have suffered adverse effects due to airborne mercury emissions.
label: paragraph

line: Field data are suggestive of adverse toxicological effects in the Florida panther due to mercury.
label: paragraph

line: Unfortunately, the interpretation of these data is complicated by the co-occurrence of several
label: paragraph

line: other potentially toxic compounds, habitat degradation, and loss of genetic diversity. Field data
label: paragraph

line: suggest that bald eagles have not suffered adverse toxic effects due to airborne mercury
label: paragraph

line: emissions.
